images.copyright: Oud-West neighborhood, Amsterdam, Netherlands (© George Pachantouris/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Oud-West neighbourhood, Amsterdam, Netherlands
images.desc: Welcome to Amsterdam! The capital of the Netherlands intrigues visitors from all over the world with its historic canals, versatile architecture and laidback atmosphere. The city's history can be traced back to the 12th century when it was a fishing village on the banks of the Amstel River. Today, it boasts institutions like the Van Gogh Museum, the Eye Film Museum and the National Maritime Museum, which offer insights into the country's history and arts legacy. Amsterdam's canal ring area, built around the turn of the 17th century, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The city is also home to its fair share of restaurants, vintage shops and outdoor markets, especially in neighbourhoods like Oud-West, pictured in today's image. Get ready to pedal because Amsterdam's cycling culture is ubiquitous. With approximately 515 kilometres of bike lanes, it's one of the most bike-friendly cities in the world.

og.title: Oud-West neighbourhood, Amsterdam, Netherlands
og.desc: Welcome to Amsterdam! The capital of the Netherlands intrigues visitors from all over the world with its historic canals, versatile…

images.copyright: Humpback whale, Disko Bay, Greenland (© Paul Souders/DanitaDelimont.com)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Humpback whale
images.desc: Who's that in the spotlight? A humpback whale! Known for their haunting songs and acrobatic breaches, these gentle giants are a success story of the ESA. They were once on the edge of extinction due to whaling and entanglement in fishing gear, but thanks to conservation efforts, their population is making a comeback, from around 5,000 in 1966 to an estimate 135,000 today. However, our work isn't over. Challenges persist, from habitat loss to poaching. So, what can we do? Spread the word, support conservation efforts, participate in local initiatives and be eco-friendly.

og.title: Humpback whale
og.desc: Who's that in the spotlight? A humpback whale! Known for their haunting songs and acrobatic breaches, these gentle giants are a success…

images.copyright: Kirkjufell, Snæfellsnes peninsula, Iceland (© Ratnakorn Piyasirisorost/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Kirkjufell, Iceland
images.desc: From glaciers and waterfalls to volcanoes and black sand beaches, Iceland's Snæfellsnes Peninsula has 'GoT' it all. Standing here proudly is the 463-metre-high Kirkjufell. The lofty hill is often referred to as 'Church Mountain' due to its distinctive shape resembling a church steeple. You might recognise it from the 'Game of Thrones' series where it featured in a scene set north of the colossal ice wall. Because of its pyramid shape, colours that shift with the seasons, and coastal location, this nunatak—a rock formation that protrudes through an ice sheet or glacier—is a frequent subject for photographers. If you're lucky, and the weather conditions align, Kirkjufell also offers a magnificent view of the northern lights.

og.title: Kirkjufell, Iceland
og.desc: From glaciers and waterfalls to volcanoes and black sand beaches, Iceland's Snæfellsnes Peninsula has 'GoT' it all. Standing here proudly is…

images.copyright: Winter sunrise in Dedham, Colchester, England (© George W Johnson/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Dedham, Colchester, England
images.desc: Take a stroll through the wintry beauty of nature, like the picturesque fields you can see in Dedham, Colchester, England. Colchester, once the capital of Roman Britain, boasts historic sites and ruins with contributions from the Normans, Tudors and Victorians. From exploring the remains of the country's churches to wandering through the charming streets of the Dutch Quarter, where 'Twinkle Twinkle Little Star' was penned, there are captivating stories waiting to be uncovered at every turn.

og.title: Dedham, Colchester, England
og.desc: Take a stroll through the wintry beauty of nature, like the picturesque fields you can see in Dedham, Colchester, England. Colchester, once…

images.copyright: Reindeer running in snow, Alaska, USA (© Michael Quinton/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Reindeer running in snow
images.desc: Don't be surprised if these reindeer take flight! Ever since Clement Clarke Moore assigned reindeer to be Santa's helpers in his 1823 poem 'A Visit from St. Nicholas', they have eagerly contributed to the Christmas celebration. Thanks to their resilient and adaptable features, like their two layers of dense fur or eyes adapted to a wide range of light wavelengths, these mammals are accustomed to diverse environments. You likely won't see them fly, but you might find a herd migrating from tundra to forest in the North Polar Region, North America, Northern Europe and Siberia. Their hooves can expand or shrink in size depending on the season and the quality of the ground, which keeps their heavy frame, crowned with antlers, standing on stable feet.

og.title: Reindeer running in snow
og.desc: Don't be surprised if these reindeer take flight! Ever since Clement Clarke Moore assigned reindeer to be Santa's helpers in his 1823 poem…

images.copyright: Town Hall Square, Tartu, Estonia (© Westend61/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Town Hall Square, Tartu, Estonia
images.desc: Today's snapshot portrays the annual celebration in the Town Hall Square of Tartu, Estonia, which is illuminated with gleaming lights and adorned with a display of Christmas trees. Tartu, located in the region of Estonia is often hailed as the 'intellectual capital city' of the country. The city was designed by the German architect JHB Walter. Some notable attractions surrounding the square include Tartu Town Hall and the Arched Bridge. Travellers come here to visit the Emajõgi River which leads to a park adorned with historic monuments that pay homage to prominent figures from Tartu and Estonia.

og.title: Town Hall Square, Tartu, Estonia
og.desc: Today's snapshot portrays the annual celebration in the Town Hall Square of Tartu, Estonia, which is illuminated with gleaming lights and…

images.copyright: Chinstrap penguins, South Sandwich Islands, South Atlantic Ocean (© Jan Vermeer/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Chinstrap penguins
images.desc: Sometimes when stuck with family, it might be tempting to give them an earful, like this chinstrap penguin is doing here on the South Sandwich Islands, in the South Atlantic Ocean. This particular penguin gets its name from the black band beneath its head. Unlike other penguins, Chinstraps prefer nesting on rockier slopes and are an aggressive species among their kind. In their natural habitat, they primarily feed on krill and face threats from leopard seals, their main predator. Catch them in their natural habitat along with Adélie and macaroni penguins. You can tell them apart from the others by the ring—or chinstrap—around their neck and by their loud and harsh call that sounds like quite the grievance indeed.

og.title: Chinstrap penguins
og.desc: Sometimes when stuck with family, it might be tempting to give them an earful, like this chinstrap penguin is doing here on the South…

images.copyright: Castlerigg Stone Circle near Keswick, Lake District National Park, Cumbria, United Kingdom (© John Finney Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Castlerigg Stone Circle, Cumbria, United Kingdom
images.desc: According to archaeologists, ancient civilisations arranged stone circles to align with lunar and solar positions, which were used to celebrate events such as the solstice. Today's image showcases the Castlerigg Stone Circle, an ancient Neolithic monument located in the Lake District National Park, Northwest England. The impressive site dates back to 3000 BCE and boasts 40 stones arranged in a circular pattern. While some aspects of Castlerigg's solar alignments remain a mystery, the allure of its ancient charm has drawn visitors and researchers throughout the centuries.
